standard_metadata.standard_description: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

question.content: Look at the image below.    **What is the area of the triangle?**   units$^2$

images.alt: A scalene triangle. There is a dashed line that is perpendicular to the base from the base to the opposite vertex. An arrow shows the length of the base is labeled 6. The dashed line is labeled 5.

hints.content: If we add an exact copy of the triangle, we can make a parallelogram.  Then we can use the parallelogram's area to figure out the triangle's area.
[[☃ image 1]]  The original triangle has $\dfrac{1}{2}$ the area of the parallelogram we just made.

images.alt: A parallelogram. There is a dashed line that is perpendicular to the base from the base to the opposite vertex. An arrow shows the length of the base is labeled 6. The dashed line is labeled 5. The parallelogram has a line segment in diagonal corners that creates two triangles each with a base of 6 units and a height of 5 units.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of parallelogram} &= \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ \text{Area of triangle} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 6 \times 5\\\\ &= 3 \times 5\\\\ &= 15 \end{align}$
The triangle has an area of $15$ units$^2$.

question.content: Look at the image below.    **What is the area of the triangle?**   units$^2$

images.alt: A scalene triangle. There is a dashed line that is perpendicular to the base from the base to the opposite vertex. The dashed line creates two right triangles. An arrow shows the length of the base is labeled 18. The dashed line is labeled 15.

hints.content: If we add an exact copy of the triangle, we can make a parallelogram.  Then we can use the parallelogram's area to figure out the triangle's area.
[[☃ image 1]]  The original triangle has $\dfrac{1}{2}$ the area of the parallelogram we just made.

images.alt: A parallelogram. There is a dashed line that is perpendicular to the base from the base to the opposite vertex. An arrow shows the length of the base is labeled 18. The dashed line is labeled 15. The parallelogram has a line segment in diagonal corners that creates two triangles each with a base of 18 units and a height of 15 units.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of parallelogram} &= \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ \text{Area of triangle} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 18 \times 15\\\\ &= 9 \times 15\\\\ &= 135 \end{align}$
The triangle has an area of $135$ units$^2$.

The dashed line is labeled 2. The parallelogram has a line segment in diagonal corners that creates two triangles each with a base of 4 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of parallelogram} &= \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ \text{Area of triangle} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 2\\\\ &= 2 \times 2\\\\ &= 4 \end{align}$
The triangle has an area of $4$ units$^2$.

The dashed line is labeled 2. The parallelogram has a line segment in diagonal corners that creates two triangles each with a base of 7 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of parallelogram} &= \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ \text{Area of triangle} &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 7 \times 2\\\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 7\\\\ &= 1 \times 7\\\\ &= 7 \end{align}$
The triangle has an area of $7$ units$^2$.

The triangle has an area of $63$ units$^2$.
